repnme.cdata!:
Comoros - Infrastructure, Water and
            Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report derives the reasons for the
            cancellation of the Infrastructure, Water, and Environment
            Project for Comoros from the highly volatile political
            situation, the institutional vacuum, and non-transparent
            business practices.  Hopes for reconciliation and a renewal
            of government have not materialized despite the Fomboni
            Agreement reached in February 2001 to end political turmoil
            and which outlined the path to reunification and
            democratization of the country. However, new lines of
            confrontation emerged as the agreements had left room for
            interpretation and negotiation on the specific
            responsibilities and prerogatives of the four governments
            (the Union and three islands pressing for autonomy). Since
            July 2002 disagreements over budget issues emerged,
            particularly with respect to modalities of tax collection
            and customs administration. Disputes over control of
            revenues and the security forces, and mutual accusations of
            coup and assassination plots have charged the atmosphere
            further, and caused indefinite postponement of legislative
            elections for the Union and the three islands. The tensions
            between the Union and the islands are further compounded
            because Anjouan has been operating much like an independent
            entity, while Moheli and Grande Comore have never been able
            to fully exercise their autonomous prerogatives. Comoros is
            not a war-torn, post-conflict country recovering from heavy
            loss of human or physical capital. But unconventional
            business practices have flourished in an institutional
            vacuum and poor governance, as evidenced by the
            single-source contracting for the country's telephone
            code, by Anjouan's "double privatization" of
            its port, and by the lack of competitive practices for oil
            or rice imports. The setting-up of the Union and of the
            three independent islands was not properly prepared and
            to-date there is a significant lack of understanding as to
            the roles and responsibilities of the different spheres of
            government. This report points out the barriers to project
            completion as the islands' preoccupation with autonomy
            and unwillingness to accept Union oversight in any of their
            development efforts; the failure of the road fund to
            preserve investments and release resources; and the
            criticism of the role of the international expert who
            managed the project unit. The report suggests focusing
            development assistance on communities and civil society in
            situations where a functioning government is absent and
            mutual distrust exists among political leaders.

repnme.cdata!:
Comoros - Infrastructure, Water and
            Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Infrastructure, Water, and
            Environment Project for the Comoros is an integral part of a
            multi-donor-financed program, and supports the development
            objectives of the larger program. The primary program
            objective is to improve living conditions and stimulate
            economic growth in the Comoros, while protecting the
            environment through investments in basic infrastructure.
            There are three project components. The first, the transport
            component, assists Comoros with improving its road
            maintenance, safety, and management through three
            subcomponents: national and regional roads periodic
            maintenance, roads safety, and institutional strengthening.
            Specifically, these subcomponents will rehabilitate
            earthworks, including pothole repair, local reinforcement,
            resurfacing, and resealing; maintain and repair road
            shoulders, drainage works, and roadsides; finance the
            installation of traffic signals and signs and the
            stabilization of road embankments; and strengthen the
            capacity of the executing agency and privatize regional road
            maintenance centers, and provide technical assistance. The
            urban water supply component will support the rehabilitation
            and extension of urban water infrastructure, and support
            technical assistance to strengthen the management and
            operation of urban water utilities. The third component
            funds agency coordination and supports training on
            environmental management for government staff and others who
            design, implement, maintain, and operate project activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Comoros - Infrastructure, Water and
            Environment Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Infrastructure, Water and
            Environment Project will improve the infrastructure, and
            institutional management of urban water supply and transport
            in Comoros. Nonetheless, it is expected that environmental
            adversity will occur as a result of project implementation,
            namely due to construction, and rehabilitation works.
            Mitigating measures are: 1) Establishment of waste disposal
            sites, and retention schemes to drain water flows, under
            strict bacteriological quality testing of waters, to protect
            aquatic marine bio-diversity. Sewers should be covered, to
            facilitate road functionality. 2) Hydro-biological studies
            should address watershed management, particularly regarding
            water supply distribution; and, regarding the construction
            of water supply systems, protection walls should be built to
            avoid contamination, in addition to including precautionary
            clauses in the bidding documents. Engineering design will
            limit deforestation, and loss of agricultural land. However,
            potential agricultural losses include compensation, or
            resettlement to new lands of equal agricultural value,
            including new seedlings for lost fruits, and vegetables,
            accompanied by compensation for the length of time those
            seedlings remain unproductive. 3) Roads, and infrastructure
            works will require limited working hours, to abate noise and
            air pollution, including spraying to avoid dust pollution.
            Safety measures include road signaling, and an awareness
            campaign to inform the communities.
